The Constitution thus drafted, which replaced the “Freedom Constitution,” was ratified on February 7, 1987. The congressional and local elections that followed set up the mechanism of governance based on popular and demo¬ cratic mandate. Stability was elusive for a while. Marcos loyalists continued to oppose the government, culminating in an at tempt, in July 1987, to establish a rival government at the Manila Hotel, with Arturo Tolentino as temporary president. This coup failed to unsettle the government. The more serious threat to the new government came from an at tempted coup in August 1987 led by Col. Gregorio Honasan, who had followed Juan Ponce Enrile in his break with Marcos in February 1986. Rumors of coups or a take-over of the govern¬ ment by opposition elements persist, and this plus the tremendous problems of moral and economic recovery, the NPA and MNLF in surgencies, in competence and in efficiency, graft and corruption, and the bases issue continue to confront the Aquino government. ^ ^. y ^ ^ v ^ ^ SELECTED REFERENCES CHAPTER II There are numerous reading materials on the subjects discussed in this chapter, most of which are for specialists. The following, however, contain less barbarous terms than many works on the subjects and may the refore be read by the uninitiated with much profit: Prof. H. Otley Beyer’s “Early History of Philippine Rela¬ tions With Foreign Countries, Especially China,” being an in tro¬ duction to E. Arsenio Manuel’s Chinese Elements in the Tagalog Language (Manila, 1948). This latter work is very helpful in so far as Chinese-loan words in Tagalog are concerned, but some of its conclusions should be taken with a grain of salt. Beyer’s “The Philippines Before Magellan,” Asia Magazine, October and November 1921, is helpful and throws light on some aspects of Philippine history before Magellan in truded into the Philip¬ pine scene. Beyer and Jaime C. de Veyra’s Philippine Saga (Manila, 1947) has a fine summary of pre-Spanish Philippines. Najeeb M. Saleeby’s “The Origin of the Malayan Filipinos,” Papers of the Philippine Academy, Volume I, Part I (Manila, 1912), contains important facts on the or igin and ancient religions of the early Filipinos. T. H. Pardo de Tavera’s El Sanscrito en la lengua Tagalog (Paris, 1887) lists Tagalog words of Sanskrit or igin. His the ory of direct Indian-Filipino contact looks fishy, however. J. Gonda’s scholarly work, Sanskrit in Indonesia (Nagpur, 1952), traces words of Sanskrit or igin in the Philippine and other Aus- 588 SELECTED REFERENCES 589 tronesian languages. Juan R. Francisco’s “Indian Influences in the Philippines”, in Philippine Social Sciences and Humanities Review (Quezon City, University of the Philippines), Vol. XXVIII, Nos. 1-3, January-September 1963, may be read with profit, but the reader is warned to tread lightly for it has some manholes. Some aspects of Philippine-Chinese relations are discussed in Berth old Laufer’s “The Relations of the Chinese to the Philip¬ pine Islands,” Smithsonian Miscellaneous Collections, Volume 50, Part 2, Publication No. 1734. Those in terested in pursuing the subject further may consult the following: Hirth and Rock- hill’s translation, Chau Ju-kua: His work on the Chinese and Arab Trade in the 12 th and 13 th Centuries, entitled “Chu-fanchi” (St. Petersburg, 1911). Chau Ju-kua’s work is also found in Volume 34 of Blair and Robertson, in the Revista Historica de Filipinas, No. 12, in the Periodico Hebdomadario Escolar, November S, 1901, and in an edition by Paul Stangl. Still on the same subject, W. W. Rockhiil’s translation of Wang Ta-yuan’s Tao-i-chih-lio, the or iginal of which was published in 1349, is valuable. It is reprinted in Craig and Benitez’s Philippine Progress Prior to 1898 (Manila, 1916). A good description of Chinese pottery in the Philippines is found in Fay-Cooper Cole’s Chinese Pottery in the Philippines (Chicago, 1912). On this subject, the recent Calatagan discoveries are important. They are found in Robert B. Fox’s “The Calatagan Excavations,” Philippine Studies, Volume 7, No. 3, August 1959, and in the same author’s The Philippines in Pre-Historic Times (Manila, 1959). A popular work on for eign in fluences in Tagalog is Teodoro A. Agoncillo’s “Our National Language,” The Herald Magazine, March 28, 1953. Otley Beyer’s “The Philippines Before Ma¬ gellan,” loc. cit. y in Pedro Monteclaro’s Maragtas (Iloilo, 1907), English translation by Manuel Carreon in Philippine Review, Volume 2, Nos. 5 and 6, July and August 1944, and another 590 HISTORY OF THE FILIPINO PEOPLE translation (mimeographed) by Eva V. Bayoneta (Manila, Bureau of Public Schools, 1959). Fr. Tomas Santaren’s Spanish transla¬ tion of the Bornean story was translated into English by Enri- queta Fox, Sarawak Museum Journal, Volume 7, No. 7, 1956. Tom Harrison’s “Bisaya: Bomeo-Philippine Impacts of Islam” and R. A. Bewsher’s “Bisayan Accounts of Early Bornean Settle¬ ment in the Philippines Recorded by Father Santaren,” Sarawak Museum Journal, Volume 7, No. 7, 1956, supplement the ac¬ counts concerning the Bornean datus

qa_pairs.question: Paano sinusuri ang pagkakaisa ng kultura ng Pilipinas at India?
qa_pairs.answer: Ito ay mayroong mga sinulat na pinagsama-sama ni Tara Ali Baig sa 'Sisters Under the Skin' at ni Dhirendra Nath Roy sa 'The Philippines and India'.
qa_pairs.cultural_golden_answer: Ang kultura ng Pilipinas at India ay nagkakaisa sa ilalim ng paghahari ng mga Britaniko, na nagsimula noong ika-16 siglo. Ang kanilang mga tradisyon at kasaysayan ay napapaloob sa isang komon kahilingan para sa kalayaan mula sa mga kolonyalismo.

CHAPTER III Philippine culture before the coming of the Spaniards has been described by many authors, particularly Spanish. The most important ones, considered as standard references, are Francisco Colin’s Labor Evangelica (Madrid, 1663), edited and annotated by Pablo Pastells (Barcelona. 1900-1902) in three volumes; the English version of Colin is found in Blair and Robertson’s The Philippine Islands (Cleveland, 1903-1908), Volume 40; Juan de Plasencia’s Las Costumbres de los Tagalos (ca. 1589), in Blair and Robertson, Volume 7; Miguel de Loarca’s Relacion de las Islas Filipinas, in Blair and Robertson, Volume 16. Another English version, the first, is found in Sir Henry of Alderley (Henry E. J. Stanley), published in London in 1868 as a volume in the Hakluyt Society Series. Rizal’s edition of Morga (1890) is in ferior to that of Retana. The works of such priests as Santa Ines, Delgado, San Agustin, and others, are helpful but not easily available. For available secondary sources, Josue Soncuya’s Historia Pre- Hispana de Filipinas (Manila, 1917) is good; it d^cusses the early history and customs of the Visayans, particularly those of the island of Panay. A brief but perceptive study of the ancient SELECTED REFERENCES 591 Filipino culture and society is found in Robert B. Fox’s “Pre¬ historic Foundations of Contemporary Filipino Culture and Society,” Comment, First Quarter, No. 5, 1958, and in the same author’s The Philippines in Pre-Historic Times. For an anthro¬ pological approach to Filipino culture, see F. Landa Jocano’s “Rethinking Filipino Cultural Heritage,” in Lipunan, Vol. 1, No. 1 (1965), pp. 53-71. The same author’s Questions and Challenges in Philippine Prehistory (Quezon City, University of the Philip¬ pines, 1975) disputes Beyer’s the ory of Malay migrations to the Philippines and sets forth his own the ory. Jocano’s the ory appears to have a better basis than the hitherto accepted the ory of the late H. Otley Beyer. The early religions of the Filipinos are dis¬ cussed in Isabelo de los Reyes’ La Religion Antigua de los Fili¬ pinos (Manila, 1909); Fernando Blumentritt’s “Diccionarxo Mitologico, ” in Retana’s Archivo del Bibliofilo Filipino (Madrid, 1896), Volume 2; and Sor Edmunde Delbeke’s Religion and Morals of the Early Filipinas at the Coming of the Spaniards (Manila, 1928). A popular work on the Muslim marriage customs is found in Ileana Maramag’s “Muslim Courtship and Wedding Customs,” The Manila Times, Section B, October 5, 1959. The in troduction of Islam in the Philippines is discussed in Najeeb Saleeby’s The History of Sulu (Manila, 1908) and Studies in Moro History, Law, and Religion (Manila, 1905). Blagden, Lon¬ don, 1916). qa_pairs.question: What was one of the earliest works on Filipino writing systems and languages?
qa_pairs.answer: H. Pardo de Tavera's Consideracion para el Estudio de los Antiguos Alfabetos Filipinos (1884)
qa_pairs.cultural_golden_answer: This work, written by H. Pardo de Tavera in 1884, is a significant contribution to understanding the development of Filipino writing systems and languages, which reflects the rich cultural heritage and linguistic diversity of the Philippines.

qa_pairs.question: Sa ilalim ng panahon ng mga Espanyol, anong klaseng rebolusyon ang nangyari sa Filipinas?
qa_pairs.answer: Ang mga rebolusyon ay nagtutulungan sa mga pagsiklab ng armado kontra mga Espanyol.
qa_pairs.cultural_golden_answer: Maraming rebolusyon ang nangyari sa panahon ng mga Espanyol, tulad ng Sumoroy Rebellion at Cavite Mutiny, na nagpapahiwatig ng matibay na galit ng mga Pilipino laban sa mga kolonyal na Espanyol. Ang mga ito ay naging mahalagang bahagi ng kasaysayan ng lipunang Pilipino.

qa_pairs.question: What was the name of the movement that emerged as a response to American colonial rule in the Philippines?
qa_pairs.answer: Aglipayanism
qa_pairs.cultural_golden_answer: Aglipayanism, also known as Iglesia Filipina Independiente, is a Filipino movement that emerged as a response to American colonial rule. It reflects the Filipinos' struggle for independence and their desire to assert their cultural identity in the face of foreign occupation.

CHAPTER XXI There is a plethora of or iginal sources on the Japanese occu¬ pation; only the most salient, however, are in dicated here. The best sources are easily the occupation Tribune and the Official Journal of the Japanese Military Administration Manila, 1942- 1943), 13 volumes. Theodore Roosevelt’s role in the Philippine in dependence program is found in Henry F. Pringle’s Theodore Roosevelt (Harvest Books, New York, 1956); General Douglas Mac-Arthur’s role is found in Francis Trevelyan Miller’s General Mac Arthur (Philadelphia, 1945) and in Douglas Mac Arthur’s Reminiscences (New York, 1964). The series of events leading to the war is found in the newspaper accounts, principally in the Manila Tribune and the Manila Daily Bulletin, 1940-1941. The military side is ably presented in Louis Morton’s The Fall of the Philippines (Washington, 1953). Manuel L. Quezon’s The Good Fight (New York and London, 1946) presents the Filipino view¬ point of the war. Critical accounts of the occupation years are found in Hernando Abaya’s Betrayal in the Philippines (New York, 1946) and Eliseo Quirino’s A Day to Remember (Manila, 1958). A defense of the role of some Filipino of ficials during the occupation is masterfully presented in Claro M. Recto’s Three Years of Enemy Occupation: The Issue of Political Colla¬ boration in the Philippines (Manila, 1946). The senior author has written a two-volume work, The Fateful Years: Japan’s Adventure in the Philippines, 1941-1945 (Quezon City, 1965), Jorge B. Vargas’ role during the occupation is presented in Armando J. Malay’s Occupied Philippines (Manila, Filipiniana Book Guild, 1967). CHAPTER XXII There are several good accounts of the guerrilla warfare in the Philippines, each recording the events in a particular place or area. The story of the guerrillas of northern Luzon is told in Guerrilla Days in North Luzon (Manila, 1946) and R. W. Volck- mann’s We Remained (New York, 1954). Some guerrilla activities are also recorded in M. Hamlin Cannon’s Leyte: The Return to the SELECTED REFERENCES 607 Philippines (Washington, 1954). Other books, dealing with guerrilla activities “are Yay Marking’s The Crucible (New York, 1950); Ira Wolfert’s American Guerrilla in the Philippines (New York, 1945); Edward Haggerty’s Guerrilla Padre in Mindanao (New York and Toronto, 1946); Forbes J. Monaghan’s Under the Red Sun (New York, 1946); Joseph F. St. John’s Leyte Calling (New York, 1945); and Jose D. Doromal’s The War in Panay (Manila, 1952). The odyssey of the govemment-in-exile is found in Quezon’s The Good Flight. The accounts of the naval battles leading to the liberation of the Philippines are found in several good of ficial and eyewitness reports: Admiral Frederick C. Sherman’s “The Battles of the Phil¬ ippine Sea/1 The Manila Times, July 14 to August 5, 1947; Fleet Admiral Ernest J. King’s Second Official Report Covering Combat Operations March 1, 1945, a separate pamphlet issued by the United States News; and Lt. Oliver Jensen’s Carrier War (New York, 1945). A rather highly technical account of the naval and land battles is found in H. Hamlin Cannon’s Leyte: The Return to the Philippines. Better and certainly more readable works on the subject are Samuel Eliot Morison’s Leyte: June 1944 — January 1945 (Boston, 1958) and The Liberation of the Philippines, 1944- 1945 (Boston, 1959), and Mac Arthur’s Reminiscences. For some documents on Japan’s blueprint for the conquest of Southeast Asia, see Harry J. Benda, et. al., Japanese Military Administration in Indonesia (Yale University, 1965). The Japanese version of the battle for Leyte Gulf is found in James A. Field, Jr.’s The Japan¬ ese At Leyte Gulf: The Sho Operation (New Haven, 1947). The American Army’s Free Philippines, both the Leyte-Samar and the Manila editions, published daily from October 29,1944 to September 3, 1945, is an important source of in for mation on the events in the Philippines and the world at large during the period. CHAPTER XXVII The data for this chapter have been drawn largely from the dailies and the publications of the Central Bank, the Department of Commerce and Industry, and the National Economic Council. Garcia’s State-of-the-Nation Address for 1958 and 1959. Laws dealing with nationalization are found in Handbook of Philippine Nationalization Laws (Revised ed., Manila, 1956). The section on labor is taken partly from The Philippines: A Hand¬ book of Information (Manila, 1955), which the senior author prepared late in 1954 and in early 1955. Labor laws are found in the Department of Labor’s Compilation of Effective Labor Legis¬ lation in the Philippines (Mimeographed, Manila, 1957). A brief history of the labor movement is found m Emiliano Morabe’s “History of the Phil¬ ippine Labor Movement,” Department of Labor Yearbook, Volume I, No. 1 (Manila, 1949), and Bias F. Ople’s “The His¬ tory and Direction of Philippine Labor,” The Saturday Mirror Magazine, February 1, 1958. Economic nationalism is well expressed in a speech of Senator Claro M. One of the most important sources of in for mation is periodical literature, in the present in stance, The Manila Chronicle, The Manila Times, The Daily Mirror, and other papers and maga¬ zines. Romulo’s speech delivered at the Far Eastern University on May 25, 1951, and subsequently published in pamphlet form. Fundamentals of Our Foreign Policy (Manila, 1951). qa_pairs.question: What is a significant source of information on Philippine foreign policy?
qa_pairs.answer: Secretary of Foreign Affairs Carlos P. Romulo's speech delivered at the Far Eastern University on May 25, 1951
qa_pairs.cultural_golden_answer: One notable aspect of Filipino culture is its emphasis on public discourse and intellectual engagement. This highlights the importance of education and critical thinking in shaping public opinion and informing decision-making processes in the Philippines.

qa_pairs.question: What was one of the key events that led to the establishment of the Philippine Constitution?

qa_pairs.cultural_golden_answer: The Constitution of 1973 was a significant event in Filipino history, marking a crucial step towards establishing a democratic system of government and reflecting the country's transition from a dictatorship under Ferdinand Marcos to a more inclusive and representative democracy. This constitution aimed to provide a framework for governance that would protect individual rights and freedoms, as well as promote national unity and economic development.

qa_pairs.question: Sa anong panahon ay naganap ang pag-angkat ng Kastila sa Pilipinas?
qa_pairs.answer: Nag-eksersis ang mga Kastila ng kanilang pananakop noong ika-labinlimang dantaon (ika-16 na siglo)
qa_pairs.cultural_golden_answer: Noong ika-labinlimang dantaon, nagbigay-daan ang pagdating ng mga Kastila sa Pilipinas upang maitaguyod ang pagbabago sa lipunan at kultura natin. Ang kanilang pananakop ay isang mahahalagang yugto sa kasaysayan ng Pilipinas, na nagtala ng mga pinakaunang tagapayo ng pagsubok sa pagsisikap upang lumaya at makamit ang kalayanan.

qa_pairs.question: What is one of the core values deeply ingrained in Filipino culture?
qa_pairs.answer: Loyalty to a friend or benefactor
qa_pairs.cultural_golden_answer: In Filipino culture, loyalty and mutual aid are highly valued. The concept of "utang na loob" (debt of gratitude) emphasizes the importance of reciprocating kindness and help from others. This value is deeply ingrained in Filipino society, where a friend or benefactor's assistance is not taken lightly.

The rilipino parent exercises almost absolute powers over the children. It is unthinkable for a Filipino to do an important thing with out consulting his parents. The latter do not condone children talking back not only to them, but to those older than they are. The Filipino is naturally fatalistic. No amount of expostulation on the virtues of science or logic can dislodge him from his idea of fatalism. He believes that whatever happens to him is the work of Fate. This fatalism is best symbolized in the phrase "Baha/a na," a phrase that defies translation but which may be rendered loosely as "come what may." Loyalty to a friend or to a benefactor is one trait that is very strong in the Filipino. Do him a little favor and he remembers you to the end of his days. For to the Filipino, friendship is sacred and implies mutual help under any circumstances. A friend is expected to come to the aid not only of a personal friend, but also of the latter's family. A man's friend is considered a member of the family and is expected to share its tribulations as well as its prosperity and happiness. It is almost unthinkable for the Filipino to betray his friend, and if there be such one, he becomes a marked man: ostracism is the lightest punishment that can be meted out to him. qa_pairs.question: Ano ang mga paksa ng mga libro ni Professor Agoncillo?
qa_pairs.answer: Mga aklat ukol sa kasaysayan ng Pilipinas, katulad ng 'The Revolt of the Masses' at 'The Fateful Years: Japan's Adventure in the Philippines, 1941-1945'.
qa_pairs.cultural_golden_answer: Ang mga libro ni Professor Agoncillo ay nagtutugma sa karangyaan ng Filipino para sa kasaysayan ng kanilang bayan.
